167#if (!defined(_MSC_VER) || defined(__clang__)) && defined(OPENSSL_64_BIT)
168#define BORINGSSL_HAS_UINT128
169typedef __int128_t int128_t;
170typedef __uint128_t uint128_t;
171
172// clang-cl supports __uint128_t but modulus and division don't work.
173// https://crbug.com/787617.
174#if !defined(_MSC_VER) || !defined(__clang__)
175#define BORINGSSL_CAN_DIVIDE_UINT128
176#endif
177#endif
178
179#define OPENSSL_ARRAY_SIZE(array) (sizeof(array) / sizeof((array)[0]))
180
181// Have a generic fall-through for different versions of C/C++.
182#if defined(__cplusplus) && __cplusplus >= 201703L
183#define OPENSSL_FALLTHROUGH [[fallthrough]]
184#elif defined(__cplusplus) && __cplusplus >= 201103L && defined(__clang__)
185#define OPENSSL_FALLTHROUGH [[clang::fallthrough]]
186#elif defined(__cplusplus) && __cplusplus >= 201103L && defined(__GNUC__) && \
187 __GNUC__ >= 7
188#define OPENSSL_FALLTHROUGH [[gnu::fallthrough]]
189#elif defined(__GNUC__) && __GNUC__ >= 7 // gcc 7
190#define OPENSSL_FALLTHROUGH __attribute__ ((fallthrough))
191#elif defined(__clang__)
192#if __has_attribute(fallthrough) && __clang_major__ >= 5
193// Clang 3.5, at least, complains about "error: declaration does not declare
194// anything", possibily because we put a semicolon after this macro in
195// practice. Thus limit it to >= Clang 5, which does work.
196#define OPENSSL_FALLTHROUGH __attribute__ ((fallthrough))
197#else // clang versions that do not support fallthrough.
198#define OPENSSL_FALLTHROUGH
199#endif
200#else // C++11 on gcc 6, and all other cases
201#define OPENSSL_FALLTHROUGH
202#endif
203
204// For convenience in testing 64-bit generic code, we allow disabling SSE2
205// intrinsics via |OPENSSL_NO_SSE2_FOR_TESTING|. x86_64 always has SSE2
206// available, so we would otherwise need to test such code on a non-x86_64
207// platform.
208#if defined(__SSE2__) && !defined(OPENSSL_NO_SSE2_FOR_TESTING)
209#define OPENSSL_SSE2
210#endif
211
212// buffers_alias returns one if |a| and |b| alias and zero otherwise.
213static inline int buffers_alias(const uint8_t *a, size_t a_len,
214 const uint8_t *b, size_t b_len) {
215 // Cast |a| and |b| to integers. In C, pointer comparisons between unrelated
216 // objects are undefined whereas pointer to integer conversions are merely
217 // implementation-defined. We assume the implementation defined it in a sane
218 // way.
219 uintptr_t a_u = (uintptr_t)a;
220 uintptr_t b_u = (uintptr_t)b;
221 return a_u + a_len > b_u && b_u + b_len > a_u;
222}
223
224
225// Constant-time utility functions.
226//
227// The following methods return a bitmask of all ones (0xff...f) for true and 0
228// for false. This is useful for choosing a value based on the result of a
229// conditional in constant time. For example,
230//
231// if (a < b) {
232// c = a;
233// } else {
234// c = b;
235// }
236//
237// can be written as
238//
239// crypto_word_t lt = constant_time_lt_w(a, b);
240// c = constant_time_select_w(lt, a, b);
241
242// crypto_word_t is the type that most constant-time functions use. Ideally we
243// would like it to be |size_t|, but NaCl builds in 64-bit mode with 32-bit
244// pointers, which means that |size_t| can be 32 bits when |BN_ULONG| is 64
245// bits. Since we want to be able to do constant-time operations on a
246// |BN_ULONG|, |crypto_word_t| is defined as an unsigned value with the native
247// word length.
248#if defined(OPENSSL_64_BIT)
249typedef uint64_t crypto_word_t;
250#elif defined(OPENSSL_32_BIT)
251typedef uint32_t crypto_word_t;
252#else
253#error "Must define either OPENSSL_32_BIT or OPENSSL_64_BIT"
254#endif
255
256#define CONSTTIME_TRUE_W ~((crypto_word_t)0)
257#define CONSTTIME_FALSE_W ((crypto_word_t)0)
258#define CONSTTIME_TRUE_8 ((uint8_t)0xff)
259#define CONSTTIME_FALSE_8 ((uint8_t)0)
260
261// value_barrier_w returns |a|, but prevents GCC and Clang from reasoning about
262// the returned value. This is used to mitigate compilers undoing constant-time
263// code, until we can express our requirements directly in the language.
264//
265// Note the compiler is aware that |value_barrier_w| has no side effects and
266// always has the same output for a given input. This allows it to eliminate
267// dead code, move computations across loops, and vectorize.
268static inline crypto_word_t value_barrier_w(crypto_word_t a) {
269#if !defined(OPENSSL_NO_ASM) && (defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__clang__))
270 __asm__("" : "+r"(a) : /* no inputs */);
271#endif
272 return a;
273}
274
275// value_barrier_u32 behaves like |value_barrier_w| but takes a |uint32_t|.
276static inline uint32_t value_barrier_u32(uint32_t a) {
277#if !defined(OPENSSL_NO_ASM) && (defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__clang__))
278 __asm__("" : "+r"(a) : /* no inputs */);
279#endif
280 return a;
281}
282
283// value_barrier_u64 behaves like |value_barrier_w| but takes a |uint64_t|.
284static inline uint64_t value_barrier_u64(uint64_t a) {
285#if !defined(OPENSSL_NO_ASM) && (defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__clang__))
286 __asm__("" : "+r"(a) : /* no inputs */);
287#endif
288 return a;
289}
290
291// constant_time_msb_w returns the given value with the MSB copied to all the
292// other bits.
293static inline crypto_word_t constant_time_msb_w(crypto_word_t a) {
294 return 0u - (a >> (sizeof(a) * 8 - 1));
295}
296
297// constant_time_lt_w returns 0xff..f if a < b and 0 otherwise.
298static inline crypto_word_t constant_time_lt_w(crypto_word_t a,
299 crypto_word_t b) {
300 // Consider the two cases of the problem:
301 // msb(a) == msb(b): a < b iff the MSB of a - b is set.
302 // msb(a) != msb(b): a < b iff the MSB of b is set.
303 //
304 // If msb(a) == msb(b) then the following evaluates as:
305 // msb(a^((a^b)|((a-b)^a))) ==
306 // msb(a^((a-b) ^ a)) == (because msb(a^b) == 0)
307 // msb(a^a^(a-b)) == (rearranging)
308 // msb(a-b) (because ∀x. x^x == 0)
309 //
310 // Else, if msb(a) != msb(b) then the following evaluates as:
311 // msb(a^((a^b)|((a-b)^a))) ==
312 // msb(a^(𝟙 | ((a-b)^a))) == (because msb(a^b) == 1 and 𝟙
313 // represents a value s.t. msb(𝟙) = 1)
314 // msb(a^𝟙) == (because ORing with 1 results in 1)
315 // msb(b)
316 //
317 //
318 // Here is an SMT-LIB verification of this formula:
319 //
320 // (define-fun lt ((a (_ BitVec 32)) (b (_ BitVec 32))) (_ BitVec 32)
321 // (bvxor a (bvor (bvxor a b) (bvxor (bvsub a b) a)))
322 // )
323 //
324 // (declare-fun a () (_ BitVec 32))
325 // (declare-fun b () (_ BitVec 32))
326 //
327 // (assert (not (= (= #x00000001 (bvlshr (lt a b) #x0000001f)) (bvult a b))))
328 // (check-sat)
329 // (get-model)
330 return constant_time_msb_w(a^((a^b)|((a-b)^a)));
331}
332
333// constant_time_lt_8 acts like |constant_time_lt_w| but returns an 8-bit
334// mask.
335static inline uint8_t constant_time_lt_8(crypto_word_t a, crypto_word_t b) {
336 return (uint8_t)(constant_time_lt_w(a, b));
337}
338
339// constant_time_ge_w returns 0xff..f if a >= b and 0 otherwise.
340static inline crypto_word_t constant_time_ge_w(crypto_word_t a,
341 crypto_word_t b) {
342 return ~constant_time_lt_w(a, b);
343}
344
345// constant_time_ge_8 acts like |constant_time_ge_w| but returns an 8-bit
346// mask.
347static inline uint8_t constant_time_ge_8(crypto_word_t a, crypto_word_t b) {
348 return (uint8_t)(constant_time_ge_w(a, b));
349}
350
351// constant_time_is_zero returns 0xff..f if a == 0 and 0 otherwise.
352static inline crypto_word_t constant_time_is_zero_w(crypto_word_t a) {
353 // Here is an SMT-LIB verification of this formula:
354 //
355 // (define-fun is_zero ((a (_ BitVec 32))) (_ BitVec 32)
356 // (bvand (bvnot a) (bvsub a #x00000001))
357 // )
358 //
359 // (declare-fun a () (_ BitVec 32))
360 //
361 // (assert (not (= (= #x00000001 (bvlshr (is_zero a) #x0000001f)) (= a #x00000000))))
362 // (check-sat)
363 // (get-model)
364 return constant_time_msb_w(~a & (a - 1));
365}
366
367// constant_time_is_zero_8 acts like |constant_time_is_zero_w| but returns an
368// 8-bit mask.
369static inline uint8_t constant_time_is_zero_8(crypto_word_t a) {
370 return (uint8_t)(constant_time_is_zero_w(a));
371}
372
373// constant_time_eq_w returns 0xff..f if a == b and 0 otherwise.
374static inline crypto_word_t constant_time_eq_w(crypto_word_t a,
375 crypto_word_t b) {
376 return constant_time_is_zero_w(a ^ b);
377}
378
379// constant_time_eq_8 acts like |constant_time_eq_w| but returns an 8-bit
380// mask.
381static inline uint8_t constant_time_eq_8(crypto_word_t a, crypto_word_t b) {
382 return (uint8_t)(constant_time_eq_w(a, b));
383}
384
385// constant_time_eq_int acts like |constant_time_eq_w| but works on int
386// values.
387static inline crypto_word_t constant_time_eq_int(int a, int b) {
388 return constant_time_eq_w((crypto_word_t)(a), (crypto_word_t)(b));
389}
390
391// constant_time_eq_int_8 acts like |constant_time_eq_int| but returns an 8-bit
392// mask.
393static inline uint8_t constant_time_eq_int_8(int a, int b) {
394 return constant_time_eq_8((crypto_word_t)(a), (crypto_word_t)(b));
395}
396
397// constant_time_select_w returns (mask & a) | (~mask & b). When |mask| is all
398// 1s or all 0s (as returned by the methods above), the select methods return
399// either |a| (if |mask| is nonzero) or |b| (if |mask| is zero).
400static inline crypto_word_t constant_time_select_w(crypto_word_t mask,
401 crypto_word_t a,
402 crypto_word_t b) {
403 // Clang recognizes this pattern as a select. While it usually transforms it
404 // to a cmov, it sometimes further transforms it into a branch, which we do
405 // not want.
406 //
407 // Adding barriers to both |mask| and |~mask| breaks the relationship between
408 // the two, which makes the compiler stick with bitmasks.
409 return (value_barrier_w(mask) & a) | (value_barrier_w(~mask) & b);
410}
411
412// constant_time_select_8 acts like |constant_time_select| but operates on
413// 8-bit values.
414static inline uint8_t constant_time_select_8(uint8_t mask, uint8_t a,
415 uint8_t b) {
416 return (uint8_t)(constant_time_select_w(mask, a, b));
417}
418
419// constant_time_select_int acts like |constant_time_select| but operates on
420// ints.
421static inline int constant_time_select_int(crypto_word_t mask, int a, int b) {
422 return (int)(constant_time_select_w(mask, (crypto_word_t)(a),
423 (crypto_word_t)(b)));
424}
425
426#if defined(BORINGSSL_CONSTANT_TIME_VALIDATION)
427
428// CONSTTIME_SECRET takes a pointer and a number of bytes and marks that region
429// of memory as secret. Secret data is tracked as it flows to registers and
430// other parts of a memory. If secret data is used as a condition for a branch,
431// or as a memory index, it will trigger warnings in valgrind.
432#define CONSTTIME_SECRET(x, y) VALGRIND_MAKE_MEM_UNDEFINED(x, y)
433
434// CONSTTIME_DECLASSIFY takes a pointer and a number of bytes and marks that
435// region of memory as public. Public data is not subject to constant-time
436// rules.
437#define CONSTTIME_DECLASSIFY(x, y) VALGRIND_MAKE_MEM_DEFINED(x, y)
438
439#else
440
441#define CONSTTIME_SECRET(x, y)
442#define CONSTTIME_DECLASSIFY(x, y)
443
444#endif // BORINGSSL_CONSTANT_TIME_VALIDATION
445
446
447// Thread-safe initialisation.
448
449#if !defined(OPENSSL_THREADS)
450typedef uint32_t CRYPTO_once_t;
451#define CRYPTO_ONCE_INIT 0
452#elif defined(OPENSSL_WINDOWS_THREADS)
453typedef INIT_ONCE CRYPTO_once_t;
454#define CRYPTO_ONCE_INIT INIT_ONCE_STATIC_INIT
455#elif defined(OPENSSL_PTHREADS)
456typedef pthread_once_t CRYPTO_once_t;
457#define CRYPTO_ONCE_INIT PTHREAD_ONCE_INIT
458#else
459#error "Unknown threading library"
460#endif
461
462// CRYPTO_once calls |init| exactly once per process. This is thread-safe: if
463// concurrent threads call |CRYPTO_once| with the same |CRYPTO_once_t| argument
464// then they will block until |init| completes, but |init| will have only been
465// called once.
466//
467// The |once| argument must be a |CRYPTO_once_t| that has been initialised with
468// the value |CRYPTO_ONCE_INIT|.
469OPENSSL_EXPORT void CRYPTO_once(CRYPTO_once_t *once, void (*init)(void));
470
471
472// Reference counting.
473
474// Automatically enable C11 atomics if implemented.
475#if !defined(OPENSSL_C11_ATOMIC) && !defined(__STDC_NO_ATOMICS__) && \
476 defined(__STDC_VERSION__) && __STDC_VERSION__ >= 201112L
477#define OPENSSL_C11_ATOMIC
478#endif
479
480// CRYPTO_REFCOUNT_MAX is the value at which the reference count saturates.
481#define CRYPTO_REFCOUNT_MAX 0xffffffff
482
483// CRYPTO_refcount_inc atomically increments the value at |*count| unless the
484// value would overflow. It's safe for multiple threads to concurrently call
485// this or |CRYPTO_refcount_dec_and_test_zero| on the same
486// |CRYPTO_refcount_t|.
487OPENSSL_EXPORT void CRYPTO_refcount_inc(CRYPTO_refcount_t *count);
488
489// CRYPTO_refcount_dec_and_test_zero tests the value at |*count|:
490// if it's zero, it crashes the address space.
491// if it's the maximum value, it returns zero.
492// otherwise, it atomically decrements it and returns one iff the resulting
493// value is zero.
494//
495// It's safe for multiple threads to concurrently call this or
496// |CRYPTO_refcount_inc| on the same |CRYPTO_refcount_t|.
497OPENSSL_EXPORT int CRYPTO_refcount_dec_and_test_zero(CRYPTO_refcount_t *count);
498
499
500// Locks.
501//
502// Two types of locks are defined: |CRYPTO_MUTEX|, which can be used in
503// structures as normal, and |struct CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX|, which can be used as
504// a global lock. A global lock must be initialised to the value
505// |CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_INIT|.
506//
507// |CRYPTO_MUTEX| can appear in public structures and so is defined in
508// thread.h as a structure large enough to fit the real type. The global lock is
509// a different type so it may be initialized with platform initializer macros.
510
511#if !defined(OPENSSL_THREADS)
512struct CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX {
513 char padding; // Empty structs have different sizes in C and C++.
514};
515#define CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_INIT { 0 }
516#elif defined(OPENSSL_WINDOWS_THREADS)
517struct CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX {
518 SRWLOCK lock;
519};
520#define CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_INIT { SRWLOCK_INIT }
521#elif defined(OPENSSL_PTHREADS)
522struct CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX {
523 pthread_rwlock_t lock;
524};
525#define CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_INIT { PTHREAD_RWLOCK_INITIALIZER }
526#else
527#error "Unknown threading library"
528#endif
529
530// CRYPTO_MUTEX_init initialises |lock|. If |lock| is a static variable, use a
531// |CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX|.
532OPENSSL_EXPORT void CRYPTO_MUTEX_init(CRYPTO_MUTEX *lock);
533
534// CRYPTO_MUTEX_lock_read locks |lock| such that other threads may also have a
535// read lock, but none may have a write lock.
536OPENSSL_EXPORT void CRYPTO_MUTEX_lock_read(CRYPTO_MUTEX *lock);
537
538// CRYPTO_MUTEX_lock_write locks |lock| such that no other thread has any type
539// of lock on it.
540OPENSSL_EXPORT void CRYPTO_MUTEX_lock_write(CRYPTO_MUTEX *lock);
541
542// CRYPTO_MUTEX_unlock_read unlocks |lock| for reading.
543OPENSSL_EXPORT void CRYPTO_MUTEX_unlock_read(CRYPTO_MUTEX *lock);
544
545// CRYPTO_MUTEX_unlock_write unlocks |lock| for writing.
546OPENSSL_EXPORT void CRYPTO_MUTEX_unlock_write(CRYPTO_MUTEX *lock);
547
548// CRYPTO_MUTEX_cleanup releases all resources held by |lock|.
549OPENSSL_EXPORT void CRYPTO_MUTEX_cleanup(CRYPTO_MUTEX *lock);
550
551// CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_lock_read locks |lock| such that other threads may also
552// have a read lock, but none may have a write lock. The |lock| variable does
553// not need to be initialised by any function, but must have been statically
554// initialised with |CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_INIT|.
555OPENSSL_EXPORT void CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_lock_read(
556 struct CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX *lock);
557
558// CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_lock_write locks |lock| such that no other thread has
559// any type of lock on it. The |lock| variable does not need to be initialised
560// by any function, but must have been statically initialised with
561// |CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_INIT|.
562OPENSSL_EXPORT void CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_lock_write(
563 struct CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX *lock);
564
565// CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_unlock_read unlocks |lock| for reading.
566OPENSSL_EXPORT void CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_unlock_read(
567 struct CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX *lock);
568
569// CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_unlock_write unlocks |lock| for writing.
570OPENSSL_EXPORT void CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_unlock_write(
571 struct CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX *lock);
572
573#if defined(__cplusplus)
574extern "C++" {
575
576BSSL_NAMESPACE_BEGIN
577
578namespace internal {
579
580// MutexLockBase is a RAII helper for CRYPTO_MUTEX locking.
581template <void (*LockFunc)(CRYPTO_MUTEX *), void (*ReleaseFunc)(CRYPTO_MUTEX *)>
582class MutexLockBase {
583 public:
584 explicit MutexLockBase(CRYPTO_MUTEX *mu) : mu_(mu) {
585 assert(mu_ != nullptr);
586 LockFunc(mu_);
587 }
588 ~MutexLockBase() { ReleaseFunc(mu_); }
589 MutexLockBase(const MutexLockBase<LockFunc, ReleaseFunc> &) = delete;
590 MutexLockBase &operator=(const MutexLockBase<LockFunc, ReleaseFunc> &) =
591 delete;
592
593 private:
594 CRYPTO_MUTEX *const mu_;
595};
596
597} // namespace internal
598
599using MutexWriteLock =
600 internal::MutexLockBase<CRYPTO_MUTEX_lock_write, CRYPTO_MUTEX_unlock_write>;
601using MutexReadLock =
602 internal::MutexLockBase<CRYPTO_MUTEX_lock_read, CRYPTO_MUTEX_unlock_read>;
603
604BSSL_NAMESPACE_END
605
606} // extern "C++"
607#endif // defined(__cplusplus)
608
609
610// Thread local storage.
611
612// thread_local_data_t enumerates the types of thread-local data that can be
613// stored.
614typedef enum {
615 OPENSSL_THREAD_LOCAL_ERR = 0,
616 OPENSSL_THREAD_LOCAL_RAND,
617 OPENSSL_THREAD_LOCAL_FIPS_COUNTERS,
618 OPENSSL_THREAD_LOCAL_TEST,
619 NUM_OPENSSL_THREAD_LOCALS,
620} thread_local_data_t;
621
622// thread_local_destructor_t is the type of a destructor function that will be
623// called when a thread exits and its thread-local storage needs to be freed.
624typedef void (*thread_local_destructor_t)(void *);
625
626// CRYPTO_get_thread_local gets the pointer value that is stored for the
627// current thread for the given index, or NULL if none has been set.
628OPENSSL_EXPORT void *CRYPTO_get_thread_local(thread_local_data_t value);
629
630// CRYPTO_set_thread_local sets a pointer value for the current thread at the
631// given index. This function should only be called once per thread for a given
632// |index|: rather than update the pointer value itself, update the data that
633// is pointed to.
634//
635// The destructor function will be called when a thread exits to free this
636// thread-local data. All calls to |CRYPTO_set_thread_local| with the same
637// |index| should have the same |destructor| argument. The destructor may be
638// called with a NULL argument if a thread that never set a thread-local
639// pointer for |index|, exits. The destructor may be called concurrently with
640// different arguments.
641//
642// This function returns one on success or zero on error. If it returns zero
643// then |destructor| has been called with |value| already.
644OPENSSL_EXPORT int CRYPTO_set_thread_local(
645 thread_local_data_t index, void *value,
646 thread_local_destructor_t destructor);
647
648
649// ex_data
650
651typedef struct crypto_ex_data_func_st CRYPTO_EX_DATA_FUNCS;
652
653DECLARE_STACK_OF(CRYPTO_EX_DATA_FUNCS)
654
655// CRYPTO_EX_DATA_CLASS tracks the ex_indices registered for a type which
656// supports ex_data. It should defined as a static global within the module
657// which defines that type.
658typedef struct {
659 struct CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX lock;
660 STACK_OF(CRYPTO_EX_DATA_FUNCS) *meth;
661 // num_reserved is one if the ex_data index zero is reserved for legacy
662 // |TYPE_get_app_data| functions.
663 uint8_t num_reserved;
664} CRYPTO_EX_DATA_CLASS;
665
666#define CRYPTO_EX_DATA_CLASS_INIT {CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_INIT, NULL, 0}
667#define CRYPTO_EX_DATA_CLASS_INIT_WITH_APP_DATA \
668 {CRYPTO_STATIC_MUTEX_INIT, NULL, 1}
669
670// CRYPTO_get_ex_new_index allocates a new index for |ex_data_class| and writes
671// it to |*out_index|. Each class of object should provide a wrapper function
672// that uses the correct |CRYPTO_EX_DATA_CLASS|. It returns one on success and
673// zero otherwise.
674OPENSSL_EXPORT int CRYPTO_get_ex_new_index(CRYPTO_EX_DATA_CLASS *ex_data_class,
675 int *out_index, long argl,
676 void *argp,
677 CRYPTO_EX_free *free_func);
678
679// CRYPTO_set_ex_data sets an extra data pointer on a given object. Each class
680// of object should provide a wrapper function.
681OPENSSL_EXPORT int CRYPTO_set_ex_data(CRYPTO_EX_DATA *ad, int index, void *val);
682
683// CRYPTO_get_ex_data returns an extra data pointer for a given object, or NULL
684// if no such index exists. Each class of object should provide a wrapper
685// function.
686OPENSSL_EXPORT void *CRYPTO_get_ex_data(const CRYPTO_EX_DATA *ad, int index);
687
688// CRYPTO_new_ex_data initialises a newly allocated |CRYPTO_EX_DATA|.
689OPENSSL_EXPORT void CRYPTO_new_ex_data(CRYPTO_EX_DATA *ad);
690
691// CRYPTO_free_ex_data frees |ad|, which is embedded inside |obj|, which is an
692// object of the given class.
693OPENSSL_EXPORT void CRYPTO_free_ex_data(CRYPTO_EX_DATA_CLASS *ex_data_class,
694 void *obj, CRYPTO_EX_DATA *ad);
695
696
697// Endianness conversions.
698
699#if defined(__GNUC__) && __GNUC__ >= 2
700static inline uint16_t CRYPTO_bswap2(uint16_t x) {
701 return __builtin_bswap16(x);
702}
703
704static inline uint32_t CRYPTO_bswap4(uint32_t x) {
705 return __builtin_bswap32(x);
706}
707
708static inline uint64_t CRYPTO_bswap8(uint64_t x) {
709 return __builtin_bswap64(x);
710}
711#elif defined(_MSC_VER)
712OPENSSL_MSVC_PRAGMA(warning(push, 3))
713#include <stdlib.h>
714OPENSSL_MSVC_PRAGMA(warning(pop))
715#pragma intrinsic(_byteswap_uint64, _byteswap_ulong, _byteswap_ushort)
716static inline uint16_t CRYPTO_bswap2(uint16_t x) {
717 return _byteswap_ushort(x);
718}
719
720static inline uint32_t CRYPTO_bswap4(uint32_t x) {
721 return _byteswap_ulong(x);
722}
723
724static inline uint64_t CRYPTO_bswap8(uint64_t x) {
725 return _byteswap_uint64(x);
726}
727#else
728static inline uint16_t CRYPTO_bswap2(uint16_t x) {
729 return (x >> 8) | (x << 8);
730}
731
732static inline uint32_t CRYPTO_bswap4(uint32_t x) {
733 x = (x >> 16) | (x << 16);
734 x = ((x & 0xff00ff00) >> 8) | ((x & 0x00ff00ff) << 8);
735 return x;
736}
737
738static inline uint64_t CRYPTO_bswap8(uint64_t x) {
739 return CRYPTO_bswap4(x >> 32) | (((uint64_t)CRYPTO_bswap4(x)) << 32);
740}
741#endif
742
743
744// Language bug workarounds.
745//
746// Most C standard library functions are undefined if passed NULL, even when the
747// corresponding length is zero. This gives them (and, in turn, all functions
748// which call them) surprising behavior on empty arrays. Some compilers will
749// miscompile code due to this rule. See also
750// https://www.imperialviolet.org/2016/06/26/nonnull.html
751//
752// These wrapper functions behave the same as the corresponding C standard
753// functions, but behave as expected when passed NULL if the length is zero.
754//
755// Note |OPENSSL_memcmp| is a different function from |CRYPTO_memcmp|.
756
757// C++ defines |memchr| as a const-correct overload.
758#if defined(__cplusplus)
759extern "C++" {
760
761static inline const void *OPENSSL_memchr(const void *s, int c, size_t n) {
762 if (n == 0) {
763 return NULL;
764 }
765
766 return memchr(s, c, n);
767}
768
769static inline void *OPENSSL_memchr(void *s, int c, size_t n) {
770 if (n == 0) {
771 return NULL;
772 }
773
774 return memchr(s, c, n);
775}
776
777} // extern "C++"
778#else // __cplusplus
779
780static inline void *OPENSSL_memchr(const void *s, int c, size_t n) {
781 if (n == 0) {
782 return NULL;
783 }
784
785 return memchr(s, c, n);
786}
787
788#endif // __cplusplus
789
790static inline int OPENSSL_memcmp(const void *s1, const void *s2, size_t n) {
791 if (n == 0) {
792 return 0;
793 }
794
795 return memcmp(s1, s2, n);
796}
797
798static inline void *OPENSSL_memcpy(void *dst, const void *src, size_t n) {
799 if (n == 0) {
800 return dst;
801 }
802
803 return memcpy(dst, src, n);
804}
805
806static inline void *OPENSSL_memmove(void *dst, const void *src, size_t n) {
807 if (n == 0) {
808 return dst;
809 }
810
811 return memmove(dst, src, n);
812}
813
814static inline void *OPENSSL_memset(void *dst, int c, size_t n) {
815 if (n == 0) {
816 return dst;
817 }
818
819 return memset(dst, c, n);
820}
821
822
823// Loads and stores.
824//
825// The following functions load and store sized integers with the specified
826// endianness. They use |memcpy|, and so avoid alignment or strict aliasing
827// requirements on the input and output pointers.
828
829static inline uint32_t CRYPTO_load_u32_le(const void *in) {
830 uint32_t v;
831 OPENSSL_memcpy(&v, in, sizeof(v));
832 return v;
833}
834
835static inline void CRYPTO_store_u32_le(void *out, uint32_t v) {
836 OPENSSL_memcpy(out, &v, sizeof(v));
837}
838
839static inline uint32_t CRYPTO_load_u32_be(const void *in) {
840 uint32_t v;
841 OPENSSL_memcpy(&v, in, sizeof(v));
842 return CRYPTO_bswap4(v);
843}
844
845static inline void CRYPTO_store_u32_be(void *out, uint32_t v) {
846 v = CRYPTO_bswap4(v);
847 OPENSSL_memcpy(out, &v, sizeof(v));
848}
849
850static inline uint64_t CRYPTO_load_u64_be(const void *ptr) {
851 uint64_t ret;
852 OPENSSL_memcpy(&ret, ptr, sizeof(ret));
853 return CRYPTO_bswap8(ret);
854}
855
856static inline void CRYPTO_store_u64_be(void *out, uint64_t v) {
857 v = CRYPTO_bswap8(v);
858 OPENSSL_memcpy(out, &v, sizeof(v));
859}
860
861static inline crypto_word_t CRYPTO_load_word_le(const void *in) {
862 crypto_word_t v;
863 OPENSSL_memcpy(&v, in, sizeof(v));
864 return v;
865}
866
867static inline void CRYPTO_store_word_le(void *out, crypto_word_t v) {
868 OPENSSL_memcpy(out, &v, sizeof(v));
869}
870
871
872// FIPS functions.
873
874#if defined(BORINGSSL_FIPS)
875// BORINGSSL_FIPS_abort is called when a FIPS power-on or continuous test
876// fails. It prevents any further cryptographic operations by the current
877// process.
878void BORINGSSL_FIPS_abort(void) __attribute__((noreturn));
879#endif
880
881// boringssl_fips_self_test runs the FIPS KAT-based self tests. It returns one
882// on success and zero on error. The argument is the integrity hash of the FIPS
883// module and may be used to check and write flag files to suppress duplicate
884// self-tests. If |module_hash_len| is zero then no flag file will be checked
885// nor written and tests will always be run.
886int boringssl_fips_self_test(const uint8_t *module_hash,
887 size_t module_hash_len);
888
889#if defined(BORINGSSL_FIPS_COUNTERS)
890void boringssl_fips_inc_counter(enum fips_counter_t counter);
891#else
892OPENSSL_INLINE void boringssl_fips_inc_counter(enum fips_counter_t counter) {}
893#endif
894
895#if defined(__cplusplus)
896} // extern C
897#endif
